ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone interested in coastal governance/coastal issues! So beneficial!
Great class if you're interested in the issues that is touches upon - good in both breadth and depth.

Gabe was very open to discussions that were outside his area of expertise which was very refreshing at FES.The field trip for the course ran smoothly and it was clear that Gabe had put in a lot of effort in organizing it.
The field experience in St. Thomas -- It was well planned out and I learned so much!
The homemade granola bars.
The two best parts of this course were the field trip and the lab work. I also enjoyed the student presentations during the semester and on the final day.

The trip to St. Thomas provided the opportunity to observe the problems and challenges discussed throughout the course. This was most certainly the best thing about the course because many times it is hard to conceptualize things (e.g., environmental issues) without seeing it firsthand and discussing with the locals who experience these things personally.
The field trip and ability to relate the readings to our activities.
The field trip was excellent. I got an excellent overview of St. Thomas and felt like every speaker added to the experience.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: A clear itinerary for the field trip would be helpful, and what sorts of things financially the students are responsible for. Like it was unclear if we were purchasing our own tickets or not for awhile. Just logistical stuff wasn't made as clear as it could be.

I think the papers we read during the semester could have been selected more judiciously. Many of them seemed to be low quality and easy to criticize. It would be better if the selected papers were all really high quality, showing examples of really strong natural and social science research. Even if they're not from the USVI, there have to be some better papers that address similar systems and environmental problems. Also, I would have enjoyed doing some sort of service project while we were on the field trip, or at least orienting our projects from the very beginning on actually serving clients' research needs. Sandy's project on waste disposal is a great example--she spoke with several people who could use her help. If Anne Marie (TNC) had been contacted earlier, she could have provided project ideas that would have led to results she could use. I'm not sure it's feasible, but if each of us had the opportunity to arrange a meeting with someone related to our project, that would be great, too.

Some of the readings are outdated. Although there may not be some scholarly material for some of the topics, especially for St. Thomas, it may benefit the students to include some more recent sources, whether they are program efforts or current policy/economic issues. There are many program websites and efforts that exist that may help to expand the students' knowledge on these topics before they visit St. Thomas.

I think that some of the readings didn't add that much to the course (or, they were valuable but we could have used more information to connect the issues to the bigger picture, ex. the shrimp shredders one).

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Good!
Great availability and quality of help and assistance, especially since we all have different needs and experience.
Generally good, though lack of response to email was sometimes frustrating.
The instructor was responsive to all of the questions or concerns brought up during or outside of the class.
Excellent help and Gabe is an outstanding resource.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Anyone interested in coastal/water resource management issues should take this course!

Great fit for people interested in water resources management especially, found it helpful to discuss these complex interconnected issues relating to water and development, how that impacts the ecosystem, etc. Great build on previous courses taken as FES.
This course was totally valuable for my interest in marine conservation and development issues. I wish that FES offered more marine-focused courses.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn about land use impacts on coastal ecosystems.
Because everyone said it was awesome.

I took this course to expand my knowledge of environmental challenges that exist outside of the continental U.S. There are few courses available providing hands-on experience such as this course. It is especially valuable to those of us who are seeking to gain knowledge and experience in new ecosystems, especially those where many environmental and political challenges exist.
I heard that it was a great course and that the field trip is invaluable.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: YES! Far beyond my expectations!
Yes.
Yes - the course was everything I expected and more. The in-field experience was more than I expected and I found myself eager and excited to learn the topics.
Yes, this was my favorite course this semester.
Yes. The course exceeded expectations.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes -- more than I thought!
Yes.
Yes, both in class and in the field learning.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages were definitely splitting up the sampling/analytical work! Very helpful seeing as we had several samples to get through!
No work group.
Great teammates. We accomplished more than any of us could alone.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Come prepared, discuss and you will benefit so much more from the material that Gabe presents!
Make connections at your location before you go down, try to do phone interviews with people, get into the lab if you can.

Find other articles or outside sources related to the weekly readings - they will help prepare you for a better conversation on the topics. Also, do no wait until the last minute to come up with a presentation topic/project. This class gives you the rare opportunity to do work abroad, whether it is talking with locals or gathering samples. By preparing some of your project work abroad beforehand, you will gain much more from this course. Additionally, you may have the opportunity build a network in St. Thomas.
start your projects before the class trip
Great course, pick a project that you are really interested in.
